text: Seventy-ninth session
Agenda item 16 (d)
Macroeconomic policy questions: promotion of international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development
Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 24 December 2024
[on the report of the Second Committee (A/79/435/Add.4, para. 8)]
79/234.	Promotion of international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development
The General Assembly,
Guided by the purposes and principles enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations,
textWithHighlights: Guided by the purposes and principles enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations,
uncertainties: Preambular phrase 'Guided by' is not in the operative verb list; treated as no operative verb. Did not mark 'United Nations' as a mentioned entity since it appears only as part of the treaty name ('Charter of the United Nations').

text: Reaffirming its resolution 70/1 of 25 September 2015, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, in which it adopted a comprehensive, far-reaching and people-centred set of universal and transformative Sustainable Development Goals and targets, its commitment to working tirelessly for the full implementation of the Agenda by 2030, its recognition that eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and an indispensable requirement for sustainable development, its commitment to achieving sustainable development in its three dimensions – economic, social and environmental – in a balanced and integrated manner, and to building upon the achievements of the Millennium Development Goals and seeking to address their unfinished business,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* its resolution 70/1 of 25 September 2015, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, in which it adopted a comprehensive, far-reaching and people-centred set of universal and transformative Sustainable Development Goals and targets, its commitment to working tirelessly for the full implementation of the Agenda by 2030, its recognition that eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and an indispensable requirement for sustainable development, its commitment to achieving sustainable development in its three dimensions – economic, social and environmental – in a balanced and integrated manner, and to building upon the achievements of the Millennium Development Goals and seeking to address their unfinished business,

text: Reaffirming also its resolution 69/313 of 27 July 2015 on the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, which is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, supports and complements it, helps to contextualize its means of implementation targets with concrete policies and actions, and reaffirms the strong political commitment to address the challenge of financing and creating an enabling environment at all levels for sustainable development in the spirit of global partnership and solidarity,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming also* its resolution 69/313 of 27 July 2015 on the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, which is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, supports and complements it, helps to contextualize its means of implementation targets with concrete policies and actions, and reaffirms the strong political commitment to address the challenge of financing and creating an enabling environment at all levels for sustainable development in the spirit of global partnership and solidarity,

text: Reaffirming further the United Nations Convention against Corruption, which is the most comprehensive and universal instrument on corruption, and recognizing the need for its full and effective implementation, to continue to promote its ratification or accession thereto, and its full support for the Mechanism for the Review of Implementation of the Convention,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming further* the United Nations Convention against Corruption, which is the most comprehensive and universal instrument on corruption, and *recognizing* the need for its full and effective implementation, to continue to promote its ratification or accession thereto, and its full support for the Mechanism for the Review of Implementation of the Convention,

text: Recalling its resolution S-32/1 of 2 June 2021 containing the political declaration entitled “Our common commitment to effectively addressing challenges and implementing measures to prevent and combat corruption and strengthen international cooperation”, and recalling also the resolutions and decisions adopted by the Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption at its tenth session, held in Atlanta, United States of America, from 11 to 15 December 2023,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption

textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolution S-32/1 of 2 June 2021 containing the political declaration entitled “Our common commitment to effectively addressing challenges and implementing measures to prevent and combat corruption and strengthen international cooperation”, and *recalling also* the resolutions and decisions adopted by the {{Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption}} at its tenth session, held in Atlanta, {{United States of America}}, from 11 to 15 December 2023,

text: Reaffirming the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime,

text: Recalling its resolutions 65/169 of 20 December 2010, 71/213 of 21 December 2016, 72/207 of 20 December 2017, 73/222 of 20 December 2018, 74/206 of 19 December 2019, 75/206 of 21 December 2020 and 76/196 of 17 December 2021, 77/154 of 14 December 2022 and 78/140 of 19 December 2023,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 65/169 of 20 December 2010, 71/213 of 21 December 2016, 72/207 of 20 December 2017, 73/222 of 20 December 2018, 74/206 of 19 December 2019, 75/206 of 21 December 2020 and 76/196 of 17 December 2021, 77/154 of 14 December 2022 and 78/140 of 19 December 2023,

text: Recalling also its resolutions 71/208 of 19 December 2016, 72/196 of 19 December 2017, 73/186 of 17 December 2018, 74/177 of 18 December 2019, 74/276 of 1 June 2020 and 75/194 of 16 December 2020,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling also* its resolutions 71/208 of 19 December 2016, 72/196 of 19 December 2017, 73/186 of 17 December 2018, 74/177 of 18 December 2019, 74/276 of 1 June 2020 and 75/194 of 16 December 2020,

text: Taking note of the 2024 report of the Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development and its policy recommendations for combating illicit financial flows,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development

textWithHighlights: *Taking note* of the 2024 report of the {{Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development}} and its policy recommendations for combating illicit financial flows,

text: Recognizing that making progress on reducing illicit financial flows as facilitated through strengthened international tax cooperation could contribute to domestic resource mobilization and the achievement of other goals and targets in the 2030 Agenda,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that making progress on reducing illicit financial flows as facilitated through strengthened international tax cooperation could contribute to domestic resource mobilization and the achievement of other goals and targets in the 2030 Agenda,

text: Recalling the report of the High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa and its relevant contributions in increasing knowledge of the sources of illicit financial flows, and reiterating its invitation to other regions to carry out similar exercises,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa

textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the report of the {{High-level Panel on Illicit Financial Flows from Africa}} and its relevant contributions in increasing knowledge of the sources of illicit financial flows, and *reiterating* its invitation to other regions to carry out similar exercises,

text: Recalling also the high-level meeting on international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return, convened by the President of the General Assembly at Headquarters on 16 May 2019, and taking note of the Chair’s summary,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* also the high-level meeting on international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return, convened by the {{President of the General Assembly}} at Headquarters on 16 May 2019, and *taking note* of the Chair’s summary,

text: Recalling further the focus on combating illicit financial flows at the High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development, held on 26 September 2019, as well as the High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development, held on 20 September 2023,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development

textWithHighlights: *Recalling further* the focus on combating illicit financial flows at the {{High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development}}, held on 26 September 2019, as well as the {{High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development}}, held on 20 September 2023,
uncertainties: The High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development is an event rather than an organization; it is treated as a mentioned entity of type 'other'.

text: Welcoming the convening of the Summit of the Future on 22-23 September 2024 at the United Nations Headquarters in New York at which resolution 79/1 entitled “The Pact for the Future” and its annexes were adopted,
textWithHighlights: *Welcoming* the convening of the Summit of the Future on 22-23 September 2024 at the {{United Nations}} Headquarters in New York at which resolution 79/1 entitled “The Pact for the Future” and its annexes were adopted,
uncertainties: Considered whether 'United Nations Headquarters' is merely a location or should count as mentioning the UN; marked 'United Nations' as a mentioned entity.

text: Taking note of the policy recommendations of the sixth Intergovernmental Group of Experts on Financing for Development of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, and recalling the 2020 publication of the Conference on tackling illicit financial flows for sustainable development in Africa,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Intergovernmental Group of Experts on Financing for Development (UNCTAD)
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Intergovernmental Group of Experts on Financing for Development
United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

textWithHighlights: *Taking note* of the policy recommendations of the sixth {{Intergovernmental Group of Experts on Financing for Development}} of the {{United Nations Conference on Trade and Development}}, and *recalling* the 2020 publication of the {{Conference}} on tackling illicit financial flows for sustainable development in Africa,
uncertainties: UNCTAD appears in both UN Secretariat and UN System lists; treated here as UN Secretariat. The Intergovernmental Group of Experts is not in the entity list and is included as an 'other' mentioned entity.

text: Taking note also of the report of the High-level Panel on International Financial Accountability, Transparency and Integrity for Achieving the 2030 Agenda, and taking note of the recommendations by independent experts contained therein for further consideration, as appropriate,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Panel on International Financial Accountability, Transparency and Integrity for Achieving the 2030 Agenda

textWithHighlights: *Taking note also* of the report of the {{High-level Panel on International Financial Accountability, Transparency and Integrity for Achieving the 2030 Agenda}}, and *taking note* of the recommendations by independent experts contained therein for further consideration, as appropriate,

text: Recalling the conceptual framework for the statistical measurement of illicit financial flows of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, recalling further that it was endorsed by the Statistical Commission at its fifty-third session for global use as indicator 16.4.1 to measure illicit financial flows in the context of the 2030 Agenda and its indicator framework, and noting the availability of the first official estimates of illicit financial flows based on the endorsed methodology and reported for that indicator,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime

textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the conceptual framework for the statistical measurement of illicit financial flows of the {{United Nations Conference on Trade and Development}} and the {{United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime}}, *recalling further* that it was endorsed by the {{Statistical Commission}} at its fifty-third session for global use as indicator 16.4.1 to measure illicit financial flows in the context of the 2030 Agenda and its indicator framework, and *noting* the availability of the first official estimates of illicit financial flows based on the endorsed methodology and reported for that indicator,
uncertainties: Classified the Statistical Commission as an 'other' entity and normalized it as 'UN Statistical Commission' since it is not listed explicitly in the provided entity list.

text: Reiterating its deep concern about the impact of illicit financial flows, in particular those caused by tax evasion, corruption and transnational organized crime, on the economic, social and political stability and development of societies, and especially on developing countries and their progress in financing the 2030 Agenda,
textWithHighlights: *Reiterating its deep concern* about the impact of illicit financial flows, in particular those caused by tax evasion, corruption and transnational organized crime, on the economic, social and political stability and development of societies, and especially on {{developing countries}} and their progress in financing the 2030 Agenda,

text: Expressing its concern about the consequences of the smuggling of commercial goods carried out by transnational organized criminal groups and about linkages between that crime and corruption and other forms of transnational organized criminal groups, such as money-laundering and drug trafficking,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing its concern* about the consequences of the smuggling of commercial goods carried out by transnational organized criminal groups and about linkages between that crime and corruption and other forms of transnational organized criminal groups, such as money-laundering and drug trafficking,

text: Noting with great concern the severe negative impact on human health, safety and well-being caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as the severe disruption to societies and economies and the devastating impact on lives and livelihoods, and that the poorest and most vulnerable are the hardest hit by the pandemic, reaffirming the ambition to get back on track to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by designing and implementing sustainable and inclusive recovery strategies to accelerate progress towards the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to help to reduce the risk of and build resilience to future shocks, crises and pandemics, including by strengthening health systems and achieving universal health coverage, and recognizing that equitable and timely access for all to safe, quality, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics are an essential part of a global response based on unity, solidarity, renewed multilateral cooperation and the principle of leaving no one behind,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with great concern* the severe negative impact on human health, safety and well-being caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as the severe disruption to societies and economies and the devastating impact on lives and livelihoods, and that the poorest and most vulnerable are the hardest hit by the pandemic, *reaffirming* the ambition to get back on track to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by designing and implementing sustainable and inclusive recovery strategies to accelerate progress towards the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to help to reduce the risk of and build resilience to future shocks, crises and pandemics, including by strengthening health systems and achieving universal health coverage, and *recognizing* that equitable and timely access for all to safe, quality, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics are an essential part of a global response based on unity, solidarity, renewed multilateral cooperation and the principle of leaving no one behind,

text: Acknowledging that the COVID-19 pandemic has put a spotlight on the limitations of the Governments of developing countries to marshal resources in times of crisis, reiterating the need to enhance and strengthen effective domestic resource mobilization, including accountable and transparent public expenditure systems, and strengthen domestic regulatory and legal frameworks, as necessary, to more effectively counter the harm resulting from illicit financial flows, and that the harm done by such flows in straining the limited resources of developing countries evidently affects their ability to address the Sustainable Development Goal financing gap and to mobilize domestic resources for longer-term sustainable development, and recalling the meetings of discussion group VI of the informal process launched by the Secretary-General and the Governments of Canada and Jamaica on Financing for Development in the Era of COVID-19 and Beyond,
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledging* that the COVID-19 pandemic has put a spotlight on the limitations of the Governments of {{developing countries}} to marshal resources in times of crisis, *reiterating* the need to enhance and strengthen effective domestic resource mobilization, including accountable and transparent public expenditure systems, and strengthen domestic regulatory and legal frameworks, as necessary, to more effectively counter the harm resulting from illicit financial flows, and that the harm done by such flows in straining the limited resources of {{developing countries}} evidently affects their ability to address the Sustainable Development Goal financing gap and to mobilize domestic resources for longer-term sustainable development, and *recalling* the meetings of discussion group VI of the informal process launched by the {{Secretary-General}} and the Governments of {{Canada}} and {{Jamaica}} on Financing for Development in the Era of COVID-19 and Beyond,

text: Encouraging Member States to use and strengthen appropriate focal points to facilitate information exchange among one another, acknowledging the Riyadh initiative for enhancing international anti-corruption law enforcement cooperation and its Global Operational Network of Anti-Corruption Law Enforcement Authorities, as well as existing agreements, formal forums or networks, including the International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) Global Focal Point Network on Asset Recovery,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Global Operational Network of Anti-Corruption Law Enforcement Authorities
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Global Operational Network of Anti-Corruption Law Enforcement Authorities

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: INTERPOL Global Focal Point Network on Asset Recovery
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) Global Focal Point Network on Asset Recovery

textWithHighlights: *Encouraging* {{Member States}} to use and strengthen appropriate focal points to facilitate information exchange among one another, *acknowledging* the {{Riyadh initiative}} for enhancing international anti-corruption law enforcement cooperation and its {{Global Operational Network of Anti-Corruption Law Enforcement Authorities}}, as well as existing agreements, formal forums or networks, including the {{International Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) Global Focal Point Network on Asset Recovery}},
uncertainties: This is a preambular paragraph using participles; although 'Encouraging' is a directive verb, assignees/deliverables are not recorded because it is not an operative paragraph.

text: Bearing in mind that there are different sources of illicit financial flows and that a separate analysis of each source is more beneficial in designing policy responses to prevent illicit financial flows,
textWithHighlights: *Bearing in mind* that there are different sources of illicit financial flows and that a separate analysis of each source is more beneficial in designing policy responses to prevent illicit financial flows,

text: Noting with appreciation the ongoing efforts by regional organizations and other relevant international forums to strengthen cooperation in preventing and combating illicit financial flows, as well as new initiatives taken by Governments and the private sector to mobilize the financial sector in the collective fight against illicit financial flows,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with appreciation* the ongoing efforts by {{regional organizations}} and other relevant {{international forums}} to strengthen cooperation in preventing and combating illicit financial flows, as well as new initiatives taken by {{Governments}} and the {{private sector}} to mobilize the financial sector in the collective fight against illicit financial flows,

text: Noting the essential work of relevant initiatives of regional, interregional and multilateral organizations in their efforts to prevent and combat money-laundering,
textWithHighlights: *Noting* the essential work of relevant initiatives of {{regional}}, interregional and {{multilateral organizations}} in their efforts to prevent and combat money-laundering,
uncertainties: "Multilateral organizations" normalized to "international organizations"; "regional organizations" highlighted as "regional" due to non-contiguous phrasing.

text: Recognizing that combating illicit financial flows is an essential development challenge, noting that developing countries are particularly susceptible to the negative impact of illicit financial flows, and emphasizing that illicit financial flows reduce the availability of valuable resources for financing for development,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that combating illicit financial flows is an essential development challenge, *noting* that {{developing countries}} are particularly susceptible to the negative impact of illicit financial flows, and *emphasizing* that illicit financial flows reduce the availability of valuable resources for financing for development,

text: Recognizing also the importance of studying the potential relationship between combating illicit financial flows and attaining debt sustainability,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing also* the importance of studying the potential relationship between combating illicit financial flows and attaining debt sustainability,

text: Recognizing further the challenge posed by the increasing scope and complexity of illicit financial flows, and recognizing also that the need for the recovery and return of stolen assets in accordance with the United Nations Convention against Corruption requires strengthened international cooperation,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing further* the challenge posed by the increasing scope and complexity of illicit financial flows, and *recognizing also* that the need for the recovery and return of stolen assets in accordance with the United Nations Convention against Corruption requires strengthened international cooperation,

text: Recognizing that numerous technical, legal and practical challenges are to be addressed in order to facilitate the repatriation; of proceeds of crime to countries from where they were originally stolen,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that numerous technical, legal and practical challenges are to be addressed in order to facilitate the repatriation; of proceeds of crime to countries from where they were originally stolen,

text: Recognizing also that global knowledge of the importance of combating illicit financial flows and enhancing the recovery and return of assets is rapidly increasing, as is the political will to recover illicitly acquired assets by both requesting and requested States, and noting that, while many challenges remain unresolved, tackling them effectively requires a holistic approach that recognizes the different types of illicit financial flows and their impact on sustainable development,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing also* that global knowledge of the importance of combating illicit financial flows and enhancing the recovery and return of assets is rapidly increasing, as is the political will to recover illicitly acquired assets by both requesting and requested {{States}}, and *noting* that, while many challenges remain unresolved, tackling them effectively requires a holistic approach that recognizes the different types of illicit financial flows and their impact on sustainable development,

text: Recognizing further that the loss of resources caused by corruption, including complex cases such as those involving multiple national jurisdictions and vast quantities of assets, may constitute a substantial proportion of the resources of States, and has a particularly negative impact on developing countries,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing further* that the loss of resources caused by corruption, including complex cases such as those involving multiple national jurisdictions and vast quantities of assets, may constitute a substantial proportion of the resources of {{States}}, and has a particularly negative impact on {{developing countries}},

text: Reaffirming the importance of chapter V of the United Nations Convention against Corruption, and underlining that the recovery and return of stolen assets pursuant to that chapter is a fundamental principle of the Convention,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the importance of chapter V of the United Nations Convention against Corruption, and *underlining* that the recovery and return of stolen assets pursuant to that chapter is a fundamental principle of the Convention,

text: Recognizing the work carried out by the Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption, and in particular its Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on Asset Recovery, to advance the effective implementation of chapter V of the Convention,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption
Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on Asset Recovery

textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the work carried out by the {{Conference of the States Parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption}}, and in particular its {{Open-ended Intergovernmental Working Group on Asset Recovery}}, to advance the effective implementation of chapter V of the Convention,
uncertainties: Classifying UNCAC Conference of the States Parties and its Working Group as 'other' entities (rather than UN Organs/UN System) may vary by taxonomy.

text: Noting the efforts to promote the exchange of information and synergies between the open-ended intergovernmental expert meetings to enhance international cooperation under the United Nations Convention against Corruption and the Working Group on International Cooperation established by the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime

textWithHighlights: *Noting* the efforts to promote the exchange of information and synergies between the open-ended intergovernmental expert meetings to enhance international cooperation under the United Nations Convention against Corruption and the {{Working Group on International Cooperation}} established by the {{Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime}},

text: Recalling the third International Expert Meeting on the Return of Stolen Assets, held in Nairobi on 28 and 29 November 2022, and looking forward to the upcoming fourth meeting in Addis Ababa from 11 to 13 December 2024,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the third International Expert Meeting on the Return of Stolen Assets, held in Nairobi on 28 and 29 November 2022, and *looking forward* to the upcoming fourth meeting in Addis Ababa from 11 to 13 December 2024,

text: Recalling also the holding of the second session of the Illicit Trade Forum, in Geneva on 6 and 7 September 2022, which highlighted the negative impact of illicit trade, including related illicit financial flows, on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, revenue generation and economic activity,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling also* the holding of the second session of the {{Illicit Trade Forum}}, in Geneva on 6 and 7 September 2022, which highlighted the negative impact of illicit trade, including related illicit financial flows, on the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, revenue generation and economic activity,

text: Recalling further the work of the Platform for Collaboration on Tax, which is to intensify collaboration and coordination on tax issues between the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank Group and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, including on formalizing regular discussions among the four international organizations on the implementation of standards for international tax matters and on the strengthening of their ability to provide capacity-building support to developing countries,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

textWithHighlights: *Recalling further* the work of the {{Platform for Collaboration on Tax}}, which is to intensify collaboration and coordination on tax issues between the {{United Nations}}, the {{International Monetary Fund}}, the {{World Bank Group}} and the {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development}}, including on formalizing regular discussions among the four international organizations on the implementation of standards for international tax matters and on the strengthening of their ability to provide capacity-building support to {{developing countries}},

text: Noting the ongoing efforts of the joint Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/United Nations Development Programme initiative, Tax Inspectors Without Borders, to support developing countries through targeted tax audit assistance programmes,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

textWithHighlights: *Noting* the ongoing efforts of the joint {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development}}/{{United Nations Development Programme}} initiative, {{Tax Inspectors Without Borders}}, to support {{developing countries}} through targeted tax audit assistance programmes,

text: Recognizing the important work undertaken by academia and civil society in assisting Member States in understanding the challenges associated with the return of stolen assets under chapter V of the United Nations Convention against Corruption,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the important work undertaken by {{academia}} and {{civil society}} in assisting {{Member States}} in understanding the challenges associated with the return of stolen assets under chapter V of the United Nations Convention against Corruption,

text: Noting the work of the 147 members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Group of 20 Inclusive Framework on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting, which provides a forum for collaboration for tackling tax avoidance, improving the coherence of international tax rules and ensuring a more transparent and fair tax environment,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Group of 20 Inclusive Framework on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting

textWithHighlights: *Noting* the work of the 147 members of the {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Group of 20 Inclusive Framework on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting}}, which provides a forum for collaboration for tackling tax avoidance, improving the coherence of international tax rules and ensuring a more transparent and fair tax environment,

text: Noting also international developments on the implementation of the Standard for Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information in Tax Matters under a common reporting standard developed by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which 123 members have already committed to implementing by 2026, as well as the role of the 171 members of the Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes, which enables cooperation on an equal footing,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes

textWithHighlights: *Noting also* international developments on the implementation of the Standard for Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information in Tax Matters under a common reporting standard developed by the {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development}}, which 123 members have already committed to implementing by 2026, as well as the role of the 171 members of the {{Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes}}, which enables cooperation on an equal footing,

text: Reiterating the pledge that no one will be left behind, reaffirming the recognition that the dignity of the human person is fundamental, and the wish to see the Goals and targets met for all nations and peoples and for all segments of society, and recommitting to endeavour to reach the furthest behind first,
textWithHighlights: *Reiterating* the pledge that no one will be left behind, *reaffirming* the recognition that the dignity of the human person is fundamental, and the wish to see the Goals and targets met for all nations and peoples and for all segments of society, and *recommitting* to endeavour to reach the furthest behind first,

text: Acknowledges that preventing and combating illicit financial flows contributes to domestic resource mobilization, which is essential to finance policies aiming to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals;
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledges* that preventing and combating illicit financial flows contributes to domestic resource mobilization, which is essential to finance policies aiming to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals;

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Reiterates its commitment to financial integrity for sustainable development, through national efforts and international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and promote good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development, including through existing relevant international frameworks, such as the, United Nations Convention Against Corruption, while noting the ongoing work of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and the Group of 20;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* its commitment to financial integrity for sustainable development, through national efforts and international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and promote good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development, including through existing relevant international frameworks, such as the, United Nations Convention Against Corruption, while noting the ongoing work of the {{United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime}}, the {{United Nations Conference on Trade and Development}} and the {{Group of 20}};
uncertainties: Treaty reference (United Nations Convention against Corruption) not highlighted as an entity per guidance; subordinate "noting" not treated as an operative verb.

text: Reaffirms its commitment to strive to eliminate safe havens that create incentives for the transfer abroad of stolen assets and illicit financial flows;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* its commitment to strive to eliminate safe havens that create incentives for the transfer abroad of stolen assets and illicit financial flows;

text: Also reaffirms its commitment to strengthen regulatory frameworks at all levels in accordance with international standards and to further increase the transparency and accountability of financial institutions and the corporate sector, as well as public administrations;
textWithHighlights: Also *reaffirms* its commitment to strengthen regulatory frameworks at all levels in accordance with international standards and to further increase the transparency and accountability of financial institutions and the corporate sector, as well as public administrations;
uncertainties: Considered the commitments (strengthen regulatory frameworks; increase transparency and accountability) too general/aspirational to extract as deliverables; no clear assignee is specified.

text: Takes note of the work of the media in exposing corruption, tax abuse and the failings of financial integrity regulations and controls;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the work of the {{media}} in exposing corruption, tax abuse and the failings of financial integrity regulations and controls;

text: Calls upon States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption to ensure that all relevant protections are available to those who report corruption and suspected wrongdoing, noting the role that individuals and groups outside of the public sector play in preventing and detecting corruption;

assignees.assignee: States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: protections for whistleblowers

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption>> to ensure that [[all relevant protections]] are available to those who report corruption and suspected wrongdoing, noting the role that individuals and groups outside of the public sector play in preventing and detecting corruption;
uncertainties: Classified the deliverable as 'policy'; could also be interpreted as 'legislation' depending on national context. Normalized assignee as 'States parties to UNCAC' (a subset of Member States).

text: Welcomes the ongoing efforts of Member States to enhance knowledge and broaden understanding of the challenges and opportunities involved in international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets recovery and return consistent with the United Nations Convention against Corruption so as to foster sustainable development;
textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the ongoing efforts of <<Member States>> to enhance knowledge and broaden understanding of the challenges and opportunities involved in international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets recovery and return consistent with the United Nations Convention against Corruption so as to foster sustainable development;

text: Acknowledges that combating illicit financial flows requires a range of actions that includes preventing, detecting and countering such flows in source, transit and destination countries and expeditious law enforcement action and cooperation;
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledges* that combating illicit financial flows requires a range of actions that includes preventing, detecting and countering such flows in source, transit and destination countries and expeditious law enforcement action and cooperation;

text: Also acknowledges the need to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on the identification, freezing, confiscation, recovery and return of assets as one of the sources of financing for development in a broad range of areas, such as poverty eradication, food security, health, education, investment in social programmes or adaptation to climate change, and may contribute to improved sustainable development outcomes;
textWithHighlights: Also *acknowledges* the need to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on the identification, freezing, confiscation, recovery and return of assets as one of the sources of financing for development in a broad range of areas, such as poverty eradication, food security, health, education, investment in social programmes or adaptation to climate change, and may contribute to improved sustainable development outcomes;

text: Recognizes that combating illicit financial flows requires a coordinated, whole-of-government approach and therefore encourages Member States to create domestic institutional mechanisms as appropriate and necessary, including those related to digitalization or other appropriate measures to ensure information-sharing and whole-of-government coordination, in this regard invites those Member States willing to prepare integrated national financing frameworks to include plans for combating illicit financial flows, including through the transfer and sharing of data, where appropriate, and with the necessary safeguards, and looks forward to the formulation by the Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development of guidance on how countries can incorporate financial integrity actions into their financing frameworks;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Domestic institutional mechanisms
Information-sharing

assignees.assignee: those Member States willing to prepare integrated national financing frameworks

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Plans to combat illicit financial flows
deliverables.deliverable: plans for combating illicit financial flows

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Transfer and sharing of data

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that combating illicit financial flows requires a coordinated, whole-of-government approach and therefore *encourages* <<Member States>> to create [[domestic institutional mechanisms]] as appropriate and necessary, including those related to digitalization or other appropriate measures to ensure [[information-sharing]] and whole-of-government coordination, in this regard *invites* <<those Member States willing to prepare integrated national financing frameworks>> to include [[plans for combating illicit financial flows]], including through the [[transfer and sharing of data]], where appropriate, and with the necessary safeguards, and *looks forward* to the formulation by the {{Inter-Agency Task Force on Financing for Development}} of guidance on how countries can incorporate financial integrity actions into their financing frameworks;
uncertainties: Classified “domestic institutional mechanisms” as a policy deliverable; data transfer/sharing is included as an information-sharing deliverable though framed as a means within plans.

text: Notes that international cooperation in combating illicit financial flows is a work in progress that must continue to be pursued, and encourages all countries to develop effective tools and create a policy environment for combating illicit financial flows, in accordance with the existing relevant international frameworks, including the United Nations Convention against Corruption;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Policy environment for combating illicit financial flows

textWithHighlights: *Notes* that international cooperation in combating illicit financial flows is a work in progress that must continue to be pursued, and *encourages* <<all countries>> to develop effective tools and create a [[policy environment]] for combating illicit financial flows, in accordance with the existing relevant international frameworks, including the United Nations Convention against Corruption;
uncertainties: "all countries" was normalized to Member States. Consideration: "develop effective tools" could be a deliverable but is vague without specifying type; thus omitted for conservatism.

text: Recognizes that measures aimed at combating illicit financial flows require cross-border cooperation between law enforcement agencies without undue political influence and that, where requested, technical assistance can also contribute to better international cooperation, and encourages Member States, where applicable and subject to their domestic legal systems, and in line with their treaty obligations, to cooperate and exchange information and best practices in this regard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Exchange of information and best practices

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* that measures aimed at combating illicit financial flows require cross-border cooperation between law enforcement agencies without undue political influence and that, where requested, technical assistance can also contribute to better international cooperation, and *encourages* <<Member States>>, where applicable and subject to their domestic legal systems, and in line with their treaty obligations, to cooperate and [[exchange information and best practices]] in this regard;

text: Encourages countries and relevant multilateral and international organizations to continue and strengthen their efforts to provide, upon request, technical assistance and capacity-building assistance to developing countries, as well as to support African and other regional initiatives, to prevent, detect and combat illicit financial flows and to strengthen good practices on the identification, freezing, confiscation, recovery and return of assets to foster sustainable development in line with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: technical assistance
capacity-building

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<countries>> and relevant <<multilateral and international organizations>> to continue and strengthen their efforts to provide, upon request, [[technical assistance]] and [[capacity-building assistance]] to {{developing countries}}, as well as to support African and other regional initiatives, to prevent, detect and combat illicit financial flows and to strengthen good practices on the identification, freezing, confiscation, recovery and return of assets to foster sustainable development in line with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development;
uncertainties: "Countries" is mapped to Member States, though it could include non-UN states. "Support African and other regional initiatives" is not extracted as a deliverable due to vagueness.

text: Urges Member States that have not yet done so to consider ratifying or acceding to the United Nations Convention against Corruption and the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the Protocols thereto, and urges States parties to those Conventions and Protocols to make efforts towards their effective implementation;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ratification or accession to UNCAC and UNTOC
Effective implementation of UNCAC and UNTOC

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>> that have not yet done so to consider [[ratifying or acceding]] to the United Nations Convention against Corruption and the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the Protocols thereto, and *urges* <<States parties>> to those Conventions and Protocols to make efforts towards their [[effective implementation]];
uncertainties: Treaties referenced (UNCAC, UNTOC, and Protocols) are not entities in the provided list, so they are not marked as mentioned entities. Classification of deliverable types could also be seen as policy/legislation depending on interpretation.

text: Reaffirms the need for Member States to effectively implement and enforce all existing obligations under the United Nations Convention against Corruption as a critical part of combating illicit financial flows;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the need for {{Member States}} to effectively implement and enforce all existing obligations under the United Nations Convention against Corruption as a critical part of combating illicit financial flows;

text: Urges Member States to increase their efforts to prevent and counter corruption that involves vast quantities of assets and related illicit financial flows, noting that no country alone can effectively combat complex cases involving multiple jurisdictions and that international cooperation and technical assistance are needed in the prevention of and fight against corruption, including in asset recovery;
textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>> to increase their efforts to prevent and counter corruption that involves vast quantities of assets and related illicit financial flows, noting that no country alone can effectively combat complex cases involving multiple jurisdictions and that international cooperation and technical assistance are needed in the prevention of and fight against corruption, including in asset recovery;

text: Urges enhanced global efforts to trace, seize, confiscate and return criminal proceeds, in line with international obligations and domestic legal frameworks;
textWithHighlights: *Urges* enhanced global efforts to trace, seize, confiscate and return criminal proceeds, in line with international obligations and domestic legal frameworks;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee is named (likely Member States and relevant actors implicitly). The actions (trace, seize, confiscate, return) are operational law enforcement steps that do not map cleanly to the predefined deliverable categories, so no deliverables are extracted.

text: Stresses that anti-corruption measures should be an integral part of national development policies and strategies and therefore invites countries developing integrated national financing frameworks to include anti-corruption components and standards therein, as appropriate, further stresses that all jurisdictions should consider undertaking further research, policy development and programming, as appropriate, to address corruption, and decides to prevent, deter, detect and counter corruption, increase transparency and promote good governance;

assignees.assignee: countries developing integrated national financing frameworks

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Anti-corruption components in national financing frameworks
Anti-corruption standards in national financing frameworks

textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that anti-corruption measures should be an integral part of national development policies and strategies and therefore *invites* <<countries developing integrated national financing frameworks>> to include [[anti-corruption components]] and [[standards]] therein, as appropriate, *further stresses* that all jurisdictions should consider undertaking further research, policy development and programming, as appropriate, to address corruption, and *decides* to prevent, deter, detect and counter corruption, increase transparency and promote good governance;
uncertainties: Considered but did not extract deliverables for the 'further stresses' and 'decides' clauses as they are broad/aspirational (research/policy/programming; prevent/deter/detect/counter corruption, increase transparency, promote good governance) and not sufficiently concrete per guidelines. Assignee for 'invites' normalized from 'countries developing integrated national financing frameworks' to 'Member States'.

text: Encourages closer public-private sector collaboration to better tackle corruption, and stresses that further research, policy development and programming should help in reaching this goal;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* closer public-{{private sector}} collaboration to better tackle corruption, and *stresses* that further research, policy development and programming should help in reaching this goal;
uncertainties: No explicit assignees are named; collaboration and supportive actions are broad and not captured as concrete deliverables.

text: Notes with concern that proceeds derived from offences established under the United Nations Convention against Corruption have yet to be disposed of in favour of the requesting States parties, their prior legitimate owners and victims of the crimes, and decides to prevent, deter, detect and counter corruption, increase transparency and promote good governance;
textWithHighlights: *Notes with concern* that proceeds derived from offences established under the United Nations Convention against Corruption have yet to be disposed of in favour of the {{requesting States parties}}, their prior legitimate owners and victims of the crimes, and *decides* to prevent, deter, detect and counter corruption, increase transparency and promote good governance;
uncertainties: Classified 'Notes with concern' as observing (normalized to 'note') though it carries evaluative tone. 'States parties' normalized as 'States parties to UNCAC'; treaty itself not treated as an entity.

text: Urges States parties to consider, when applicable, using the international cooperation provisions of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the United Nations Convention against Corruption, in appropriate cases, to investigate and prosecute the smuggling of commercial goods;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Investigations into smuggling of commercial goods

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<States parties>> to consider, when applicable, using the international cooperation provisions of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and the United Nations Convention against Corruption, in appropriate cases, to [[investigate]] and prosecute the smuggling of commercial goods;
uncertainties: The paragraph also mentions 'prosecute the smuggling of commercial goods'. Prosecution is a concrete action but does not fit cleanly into the existing deliverable_type categories; therefore it was not annotated as a deliverable.

text: Encourages States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption to make full use of the asset recovery tools set forth in chapter V of the Convention, including mechanisms for the enforcement of foreign restraining and confiscation orders;

assignees.assignee: States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption

textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption>> to make full use of the asset recovery tools set forth in chapter V of the Convention, including mechanisms for the enforcement of foreign restraining and confiscation orders;
uncertainties: No concrete deliverable was extracted since "make full use of asset recovery tools" is implementation-oriented rather than a discrete output fitting the deliverable categories. The treaty (UNCAC) is referenced but not treated as a mentioned entity, as treaties are not in the entity list.

text: Calls upon all States parties to the United Nations Convention against Corruption, in particular requesting and requested States parties, to cooperate to recover the proceeds of crime as defined in the Convention, and to fulfil their obligation to ensure the return or disposal of such proceeds, in accordance with article 57 of the Convention, and invites States parties, in accordance with their respective domestic laws, to consider allocating recovered resources to finance the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and to strengthening the implementation of existing multilateral legal instruments for the purpose of asset recovery and return;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: asset recovery (proceeds of crime)
return/disposal of recovered assets
deliverables.deliverable: return or disposal of such proceeds

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: allocate recovered assets for SDGs
strengthen implementation of multilateral legal instruments on asset recovery and return
deliverables.deliverable: strengthening the implementation of existing multilateral legal instruments

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* all <<States parties>> to the United Nations Convention against Corruption, in particular requesting and requested <<States parties>>, to cooperate to [[recover the proceeds of crime]] as defined in the Convention, and to fulfil their obligation to ensure the [[return or disposal of such proceeds]], in accordance with article 57 of the Convention, and *invites* <<States parties>>, in accordance with their respective domestic laws, to consider [[allocating recovered resources]] to finance the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and to [[strengthening the implementation of existing multilateral legal instruments]] for the purpose of asset recovery and return;
uncertainties: Mapped asset recovery/return to 'financial_resources' as closest category; 'strengthening the implementation' classified under 'policy' though it concerns legal instruments.

text: Requests the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, in coordination with the Stolen Asset Recovery Initiative, to continue to expand global knowledge and data collection on asset recovery and return by gathering and sharing information on challenges and good practices, as well as on volumes of assets frozen, seized, confiscated and returned in relation to corruption offences, and the number and types of cases, as appropriate, while ensuring the protection of personal data and privacy rights, drawing upon existing efforts, within existing resources;

assignees.assignee: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Gather information on asset recovery and return
Share information on asset recovery and return

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime>>, in coordination with the {{Stolen Asset Recovery Initiative}}, to continue to expand global knowledge and data collection on asset recovery and return by [[gathering]] and [[sharing information]] on challenges and good practices, as well as on volumes of assets frozen, seized, confiscated and returned in relation to corruption offences, and the number and types of cases, as appropriate, while ensuring the protection of personal data and privacy rights, drawing upon existing efforts, within existing resources;
uncertainties: StAR is referenced "in coordination with" UNODC; treated as a mentioned entity rather than a co-assignee.

text: Stresses that efforts in international tax cooperation should be universal in approach and scope and fully take into account the different needs and capacities of all countries, in particular the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries, small island developing States and African countries;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that efforts in international tax cooperation should be universal in approach and scope and fully take into account the different needs and capacities of all countries, in particular the {{least developed countries}}, {{landlocked developing countries}}, {{small island developing States}} and {{African countries}};

text: Encourages further efforts by relevant national and international actors to mitigate transfer pricing not in line with the arm’s length principle and trade misinvoicing;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* further efforts by relevant national and international actors to mitigate transfer pricing not in line with the arm’s length principle and trade misinvoicing;
uncertainties: "relevant national and international actors" is too vague to map to specific assignees (e.g., Member States or international organizations), so no assignee was recorded. The mitigation actions are not concrete enough to code as deliverables.

text: Calls upon all countries to work together to eliminate base erosion and profit shifting and to ensure that all companies, including multinationals, pay taxes to the Governments of countries where economic activity occurs and value is created, in accordance with national and international laws and policies;
textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<all countries>> to work together to eliminate base erosion and profit shifting and to ensure that all {{companies, including multinationals}}, pay taxes to the Governments of countries where economic activity occurs and value is created, in accordance with national and international laws and policies;
uncertainties: No concrete deliverables extracted; the requests to "work together" and to "ensure companies pay taxes where value is created" are broad policy outcomes rather than specific outputs (e.g., a report, meeting, or policy instrument).

text: Also calls upon all countries to cooperate, in accordance with applicable bilateral or multilateral agreements, in the areas of mutual legal assistance, administrative assistance and the exchange of information in tax matters, as well as the automatic exchange of financial account information;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: mutual legal assistance
administrative assistance
exchange of tax information
deliverables.deliverable: exchange of information in tax matters

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: automatic exchange of financial account information
deliverables.deliverable: automatic exchange of financial account information

textWithHighlights: Also *calls upon* <<all countries>> to cooperate, in accordance with applicable bilateral or multilateral agreements, in the areas of [[mutual legal assistance]], [[administrative assistance]] and the [[exchange of information in tax matters]], as well as the [[automatic exchange of financial account information]];

text: Notes with concern that developing countries face obstacles in receiving information, and calls upon existing parties to information-exchange agreements to strengthen the cooperation necessary to assist interested developing countries that are parties to such agreements in accessing and using relevant information provided under such agreements, and provide capacity-building, where possible, to developing countries to meet the relevant standards;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Access to and use of information under exchange agreements
Capacity-building support to developing countries

textWithHighlights: *Notes with concern* that {{developing countries}} face obstacles in receiving information, and *calls upon* <<existing parties to information-exchange agreements>> to strengthen the cooperation necessary to assist interested {{developing countries}} that are parties to such agreements in [[accessing and using relevant information]] provided under such agreements, and provide [[capacity-building]], where possible, to {{developing countries}} to meet the relevant standards;
uncertainties: Assignee 'existing parties to information-exchange agreements' is normalized to 'Member States', though in practice it refers specifically to those states that are parties to such agreements. The deliverable 'accessing and using relevant information' is categorized as information_sharing; some may frame it as technical_assistance.

text: Invites signatories to bilateral or multilateral tax transparency agreements to consider allowing information exchanged pursuant to those agreements to be used where permitted under such agreements and when written consent is provided, having regard to confidentiality and domestic law limitations;

assignees.assignee_normalized: signatories to bilateral or multilateral tax transparency agreements
assignees.assignee: signatories to bilateral or multilateral tax transparency agreements

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Allow use of exchanged tax information
deliverables.deliverable: information exchanged pursuant to those agreements to be used

textWithHighlights: *Invites* <<signatories to bilateral or multilateral tax transparency agreements>> to consider allowing [[information exchanged pursuant to those agreements to be used]] where permitted under such agreements and when written consent is provided, having regard to confidentiality and domestic law limitations;

text: Invites the Economic and Social Council to update and strengthen the United Nations code of conduct on cooperation in combating international tax evasion in response to new international agreements and to emphasize the importance of developing countries being able to benefit from international tax cooperation;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Updated UN code of conduct on cooperation against international tax evasion
Emphasize importance of developing countries benefiting from international tax cooperation

textWithHighlights: *Invites* the <<Economic and Social Council>> to update and strengthen the [[United Nations code of conduct]] on cooperation in combating international tax evasion in response to new international agreements and to [[emphasize the importance]] of {{developing countries}} being able to benefit from international tax cooperation;
uncertainties: Classified the code of conduct task under standards (could also be seen as policy). The second task is categorized as information_sharing since it is advocacy/communication-focused.

text: Recognizes the importance of the consideration of international tax cooperation at the United Nations, in that regard takes note with appreciation of the work of the Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters, and invites the Economic and Social Council to explore options to strengthen the role of the Committee while giving due consideration to the need that efforts in international tax cooperation should be universal in approach and scope;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Options to strengthen the role of the Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters

textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the importance of the consideration of international tax cooperation at the {{United Nations}}, in that regard *takes note with appreciation* of the work of the {{Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters}}, and *invites* the <<Economic and Social Council>> to [[explore options]] to strengthen the role of the Committee while giving due consideration to the need that efforts in international tax cooperation should be universal in approach and scope;
uncertainties: The 'Committee of Experts on International Cooperation in Tax Matters' is not in the provided entity list; classified as 'other'. The deliverable 'explore options' is categorized as 'analysis'—could also be viewed as preparatory policy/strategy work, but 'analysis' seems closest.

text: Takes note of the ongoing work on the implementation of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Group of 20 two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy, acknowledges the need for a careful analysis of the implications for developing countries, and encourages a special focus on their unique needs and capacities;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the ongoing work on the implementation of the {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development}}/{{Group of 20}} two-pillar solution to address the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy, *acknowledges* the need for a careful analysis of the implications for {{developing countries}}, and *encourages* a special focus on their unique needs and capacities;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee is stated for the directive verb 'encourages'; the target audience is implied (those involved in the OECD/G20 two-pillar work). No concrete deliverables are specified.

text: Also takes note of the report on the second session of the Ad Hoc Committee to Draft Terms of Reference for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation and the completion by the Committee of its work, including the annexed Draft Terms of Reference for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation, which recognized, among other specific priority areas, measures against tax-related illicit financial flows as a potential early protocol;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Ad Hoc Committee to Draft Terms of Reference for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation

textWithHighlights: Also *takes note of* the report on the second session of the {{Ad Hoc Committee}} to Draft Terms of Reference for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation and the completion by the Committee of its work, including the annexed Draft Terms of Reference for a United Nations Framework Convention on International Tax Cooperation, which recognized, among other specific priority areas, measures against tax-related illicit financial flows as a potential early protocol;

text: Recalls the analysis, in the Financing for Sustainable Development Report 2022, the Trade and Development Report 2021 of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and World Economic Situation and Prospects 2022 of the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the Secretariat, of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Group of 20 two-pillar solution, and calls for inclusive discussions to address the uncertainties and implications for developing countries, including their capacity-building needs;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
Department of Economic and Social Affairs
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: inclusive discussions

textWithHighlights: *Recalls* the analysis, in the Financing for Sustainable Development Report 2022, the Trade and Development Report 2021 of the {{United Nations Conference on Trade and Development}} and World Economic Situation and Prospects 2022 of the {{Department of Economic and Social Affairs}} of the {{Secretariat}}, of the {{Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development}}/{{Group of 20}} two-pillar solution, and *calls for* [[inclusive discussions]] to address the uncertainties and implications for {{developing countries}}, including their capacity-building needs;
uncertainties: Treated “inclusive discussions” as a concrete meeting-type deliverable. OECD and G20 are not in the provided entity list; marked as type 'other'.

text: Also recalls that new technologies can both increase efficiency in revenue collection and strengthen the efforts to combat illicit financial flows, expresses concern that virtual assets are being used for illicit activities, and in this regard encourages Member States and other relevant organizations to take measures in line with international standards, where applicable, to prevent and counter their illicit use;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Prevent and counter illicit use of virtual assets
deliverables.deliverable: prevent and counter their illicit use

textWithHighlights: *Also recalls* that new technologies can both increase efficiency in revenue collection and strengthen the efforts to combat illicit financial flows, *expresses concern* that virtual assets are being used for illicit activities, and in this regard *encourages* <<Member States>> and other relevant organizations to take measures in line with international standards, where applicable, to [[prevent and counter their illicit use]];
uncertainties: "Other relevant organizations" is not captured as an assignee due to lack of specificity. The deliverable is categorized as "policy" since it directs taking measures to prevent/counter illicit use, though the exact nature of measures is not specified.

text: Notes that various jurisdictions have introduced mechanisms to increase beneficial ownership transparency, including beneficial ownership registries of legal entities and legal arrangements, such as companies, trusts and limited liability partnerships, encourages all jurisdictions to consider establishing appropriate mechanisms through either a registry of beneficial ownership or an alternative mechanism, in line with domestic law and applicable international standards, and encourages Member States to facilitate the timely availability of adequate, accurate and up-to-date beneficial ownership information;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Beneficial ownership registry
Availability of beneficial ownership information

textWithHighlights: *Notes* that various jurisdictions have introduced mechanisms to increase beneficial ownership transparency, including beneficial ownership registries of legal entities and legal arrangements, such as companies, trusts and limited liability partnerships, *encourages* all <<jurisdictions>> to consider establishing appropriate mechanisms through either a [[registry of beneficial ownership]] or an alternative mechanism, in line with domestic law and applicable international standards, and *encourages* <<Member States>> to facilitate the timely availability of adequate, accurate and up-to-date [[beneficial ownership information]];
uncertainties: "Jurisdictions" is not a standard entity in the list; treated as other. The deliverable category for a registry is set to infrastructure (systems), which may overlap with policy depending on interpretation.

text: Also notes that a wide variety of individuals and entities are involved in the transactions that comprise an illicit financial flow, recognizes the need to consider appropriate business regulatory policies, taking into account national circumstances, and in this regard requests the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development to jointly prepare a global mapping of existing standards and guidelines, in consultation with all relevant stakeholders, taking into account national circumstances, and to submit these to the Economic and Social Council for intergovernmental discussion;

assignees.assignee: Department of Economic and Social Affairs
United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Global mapping of existing standards and guidelines
Submission of global mapping to ECOSOC for intergovernmental discussion

textWithHighlights: Also *notes* that a wide variety of individuals and entities are involved in the transactions that comprise an illicit financial flow, *recognizes* the need to consider appropriate business regulatory policies, taking into account national circumstances, and in this regard *requests* the <<Department of Economic and Social Affairs>>, the <<United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime>> and the <<United Nations Conference on Trade and Development>> to jointly prepare a [[global mapping]] of existing standards and guidelines, in consultation with all relevant stakeholders, taking into account national circumstances, and to [[submit these]] to the {{Economic and Social Council}} for intergovernmental discussion;
uncertainties: UNCTAD can be classified as UN Secretariat or UN System; chosen UN Secretariat for consistency. The deliverable type for “submit these” is ambiguous (could be briefing or information sharing); categorized as report since it concerns submitting a document.

text: Calls upon States to effectively investigate and refer for prosecution professional service providers who are involved in or enable criminal activities related to illicit financial flows, including corruption, tax evasion and money-laundering in accordance with national legislation, and to scale up international cooperation in this regard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Investigations of professional service providers involved in illicit financial flows

textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<States>> to effectively [[investigate]] and refer for prosecution professional service providers who are involved in or enable criminal activities related to illicit financial flows, including corruption, tax evasion and money-laundering in accordance with national legislation, and to scale up international cooperation in this regard;
uncertainties: 'Refer for prosecution' and 'scale up international cooperation' are concrete asks but do not map cleanly to the available deliverable categories; therefore they were not annotated as deliverables.

text: Recognizes the significant progress and availability of concepts and tested methods to measure illicit financial flows, notes the outcomes of pilot studies across three continents showing that measurement of these flows is possible, while challenging, and requires strengthened support, and calls for increased transparency and the strengthening of efforts to enhance the capacity of national authorities for data collection and analysis to combat illicit financial flows with more informed and targeted policy efforts, emphasizing the need to strengthen national capacity to measure illicit financial flows in the context of the 2030 Agenda and increase the exchange of data within national government institutions as well as from international institutions;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: increase transparency
build capacity of national authorities for data collection and analysis
deliverables.deliverable: capacity of national authorities for data collection and analysis

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: strengthen national capacity to measure illicit financial flows
